$\mathbb{P}_n$ is space of polynomials with degree $\leq n$
Provably a space

Linear transformations on $\mathbb{P}_n$

We also have $\mathbb{R}^{m \times n}$, $C([0,1])$

The standard linear transformation on functions is $T(f) = f'$ (i.e., the derivative operator is a linear transformation)

Ex:
Q: Show that $1,x,x^2,x^3$ are linearly independent

A: Assume there are constants $a_i$ such that $a_1 + a_2x + \dots + a_4x^3 = 0$

Then $p(0) = p(1) = \dots = p(3) = 0$
And $p(x) = (x-0)(x-1)(x-2)(x-3) + q(x)$, which is $4^{th}$ degree. Contradiction.

One fashion of examining linear independence is the same as earlier $c_1p_1 + c_2p_2 + c_3p_3 = 0$

To impose a coordinate structure on polynomials, we use a slight (but intuitive) trick of notation
